document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the genus Callaspidia Dahlbom, 1842 (Hym.: Figitidae: Aspicerinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the genus Callaspidia Dahlbom, 1842 (Hym.: Figitidae: Aspicerinae)

bibRefCitation.author: Dahlbom
bibRefCitation.refString: Dahlbom, G. (1842) Onychia och Callaspidia. tvenne for Skanidnaviens Fauna nya Insekt-Slagen, horande till Gallaple- Stekelarnes naturlinga grupp. Lund, Tryckt uti Akademiska Boktryckeriet, 1 - 16 + 9 figs.

subSubSection.paragraph: ( Figs. 2b, 2e , 4b , 7b )

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Callaspidia fonscolombei Giraud 1856: 186
(injustificated emendation of
Callaspidia defonscolombei Dahlbom
).

Callaspidia westwoodi Dahlbom, 1842
; synonymized by
Hellén 1958: 54
.

Callaspidia dufouri Giraud, 1860
; synonymized by
Hellén 1958: 54
.

Onychia westwoodi Reinhard, 1860: 238
(non
Callaspidia westwoodi Dahlbom, 1842
); synonymyzed with
Callaspidia dufouri Giraud
by
Dalla Torre & Kieffer, 1910: 66
.

Onychia nigripes Cameron, 1879: 112
, synonymized in
Cameron, 1890: 177
;
Dalla Torre, 1893: 8
;
Quinlan, 1974: 17
. Synonymy here confirmed.

Callaspidia provancheri Ashmead
; restored in
Dalla Torre & Kieffer, 1910: 63
& 68

Callaspidia dufouri
ssp
vitripennis (Kieffer) Dalla Torre & Kieffer, 1910: 66

Callaspidia fonscolombei
ssp minima (Kieffer)
Dalla Torre & Kieffer, 1910: 64
n. syn.

bibRefCitation.author: Dettmer
bibRefCitation.refString: Dettmer, H. S. J. (1924) Neue Cynipiden aus den Niederlanden. Natuurhisorisch Maandblad Maastricht, 13 (9), 126 - 127.

.

Diagnosis. Similar to
Callaspidia dahlbomi
; both have transverse carinae on lateral face of pronotum and on scutum. Their frons is very rugose or carinated, but in
C. defonscolombei
, the central area of the propodeum is not transversely carinated like in
C. dahlbomi
and propodeal carinae are never divergent.
Redescription. Length . Male 3.20 to 4.20 mm .; Female 3.64 to 5.00 mm.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Head and mesosoma in lateral view of: (a)
Callaspidia notata
and (b)
C. aberrans
.

FIGURE 4. Head and mesosoma in lateral view of: (a)
Callaspidia dahlbomi
n. sp.
and (b)
C. defonscolombei
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Coloration . Head from black to medium brown, sometimes orangeish near mandibulae, antenal foramina or eye; mesosoma from black to brown, basal 1/3 and sometimes parascutal sulcus reddish or orange; pronotum black or brown, lighter anteriorly. Metanotum blackish to medium brown.

Head. Frons rugose or transversely carinated, slightly coriaceous (more noticeable in males), frontal carina present complete and wide, weakly coriaceous. Lateral frontal carina straight or slightly curved, prominent and slightly alutaceous, space between it and eye alutaceous with noticeable transverse carinae. Vertex shining to weakly coriaceous, with two to four cells. Gena rounded to weakly angled, slightly expanded, with conspicuous transverse carinae, weakly alutaceous. Occiput shining and with transverse carinae.

Mesosoma. Lateral surface of pronotum coriaceous, with uniform, irradiant, wide and spaced carinae (smaller in males), basal ones can be much wider than dorsal ones. Mesoescutum coriaceous (stronger in males), transversely carinated, carinae variable in width, straight and uniform between notauli, slightly disordered and less conspicuous laterally. Notauli hardly widen basally, inside some conspicuous transversal carinae and alutaceous to coriaceous. Median mesoscutural furrow much wider than base of notauli with same interior sculpture than notauli. Parascutal sulcus with evident transverse carinae, shining, rarely coriaceous in anterior half. Antero-admedial lines slightly prominent and generally thin, more prominent in males, reaching 1/3 to 1/2 of the scutum length, alutaceous dorsally. Median ridge alutaceous dorsally and usually thicker than antero-admedial lines. Mesonotum, in lateral view, simply curved, with no inflexions. Interfoveal carina, in lateral view, slightly above level of lateral margins of scutellum, or at same level than these, which are slightly confluent. Propodeal carinae slightly curved externally, internally very slightly curved, internal area coriaceous with occasional blunt transversal carinae.
Wings. R2 slightly curved; R1 absent. Brownish to nearly hyaline. Occasionally veins of areolet partially visible.
Variability. Nearctic individuals tend to be slightly less robust, sometimes the pronotal carinae are thinner. Moreover, in the Palaearctic specimens, the wings are more infuscate in general.

Biology. According to Weems (1954) , in North America, this species attacks larvae of Syrphidae , but he was not able to identify to which species these larvae belonged to. According to Ferguson (1986), the biology of
Callaspidia defonscolombei
has been studied by Rotheray (1979) , who collected this species from the syrphids:
Syrphus ribesii (Linnaeus, 1758)
,
S. vitripennis Meigen, 1822
,
Meligramma cincta (Falln, 1817)
,
Sphaerophoria scripta (Linnaeus, 1758)
,
Melanostoma scalare (Fabricius, 1794)
,
Platycheirus manicatus (Meigen, 1822)
and
Episyrphus balteatus (De Geer, 1776)
. According to the labels of the material studied here (see above), in Canada , this species was collected from
Dioryctria abietella
( Lepidoptera : Pyralidae ) but this host is unlikely, this species was also collected in USA from
Syrphus ribesii (Linnaeus, 1758)
and in Russia from
Syrphus balteatus (De Geer, 1776)
.

Distribution. Holarctic and Neotropical. Known from Austria , Canada , Germany , India , Italy , Russia and Spain , ( Dalla Torre & Kieffer, 1910 ), from Sweden and Great Britain ( Dalla Torre & Kieffer, 1910 ; Quinlan, 1974 ), from Finland ( Hellén, 1937 ; 1958 ), from Bulgaria , Croatia , Greece and Turkmenistan ( Hellén, 1958 ), Kazhakastan, Turkmenistan and Russia ( Belizin, 1961 ), Polonia ( Kierych, 1985 ), Slovenia ( Miczulski, 1967 ; Kierych, 1985 ), Portugal ( Madeira , Graham, 1986 ) the United Kingdom and Taiwan (Fereguson 1986); new cites in this study from Argentina , Armenia , Brazil , Chile , China , Denmark , France , Hungary , Kazakhstan , Moldavia , Netherlands , Norway , Romania , Ukraine , and USA .

Taxonomic comments. The type series of Callaspidia defonscolombei Dahlbom is deposited in ZMLU. It was possible to identify it because Dahlbom (1842) specifies in his work the localities where the specimens were collected and also the dates of collection. In the original description five Scandinavian specimens are studied ( Dahlbom, 1842: 13 ). One of these specimens corresponds to a new species described here, Callaspidia dahlbomi , exactly the female collected in Furillen in 21.VII.1841 , together with the type material of C. westwoodi according to Dahlbom (1842: 14 and 15). Thus, the type material of this species is formed by four exemplars. The lectotype is the only specimen with the collection data included; the paratypes correspond to a male collected by Professor Zetterstedt (according to Dahlbom, 1842: 13 ) and two females without collection data (according to Dahlbom, 1842: 14 ). One specimen with the label “ZML.1998 278” was considered by Weld (1931) as the type and this was subsequently studied by Quinlan (1973) (see additional material from Sweden ); nevertheless, this specimen corresponds to a male collected in Faröen in 25.VII.41 and does not belong to the type series because this data is not mentioned in the original descriptions. In addition, the type series has only a male and it is included as mentioned above.

The type series of
Callaspidia westwoodi
is deposited in ZMLU. Dalhlbom (1842) mentions that the two males were collected in Furillen in 21.VII.1841 at the same time as a female of
Callaspidia defonscolombei
. These three specimens have been found. One male of
C. westwoodi
is deposited in Dahlbom’s collection and the other one in Thomson’s collection according to R. Danielson’s notes in the loan document (Danielson, pers. comm .).

Dahlbom (1842: 13) considered
Figites notata Boyer de Fonscolombe, 1832
, as a synonym of
C. defonscolombei Dahlbom. As Graham
mentions (1986: 39), if this is the case, ‘
notata
’ would have preference over ‘
defonscolombei
’. Ferguson, in Graham (1986) , suggested that both species are different. After examining the type material of
Callaspidia notata (Fonscolombe)
and of
Callaspidia defonscolombei Dahlbom
, we can assert that they are different species, as the distribution and abundance of the lateral carinae in the pronotum clearly separate these two species ( Figs 3a , 4b ).

We assume that the synonymy of
Callaspidia dufouri Giraud, 1860
with
C. defonscolombei
was established by Hellén 1958 (see the list of synonymies) since we consider that Hellén (1958: 54) mistakes the authorship of the first aforementioned species, as he erroneously assigns
C. dufouri
to Dahlbom instead of Giraud, as would be correct.

Neither the original description by Kieffer (1901a) of
Callaspidia dufouri vitripennis
nor Kieffer (1902) provide a diagnostic character that allows us to differentiate this subspecies from
C. defonscolombei
(=
C. dufouri
). For this reason
Callaspidia dufouri vitripennis (Kieffer, 1901)
is considered in this study as a new synonymy of
C. defonscolombei Dahlbom, 1842
.

Kieffer (1901b) describes a new variety named ‘ minima ’ that is subsequently considered a subspecies by Dalla Torre & Kieffer (1910) . Kieffer (1901b) states that the variety ‘ minima ’ is differentiated from the type of
C. defonscolombei
by the antenna (which have the same length as the body, the third antennomere is bigger than the fourth and the 14th is 2.0 times longer than the 13th) the triangular area of the mesonotum is slightly longer than wide, and the lateral margins (we assume them to be antero-admedial lines) are interrupted before reaching the end of the median ridge. All these characteristics form part of the intraspecific variability of
C. defonscolombei
, which has been observed when studying long series of this species. For all these reasons, we consider
Callaspidia defonscolombei minima (Kieffer, 1901)
as a new synonymy of
C. defonscolombei Dahlbom, 1842
.

The type of
Callaspidia rubricrus Dettmer, 1924
, is probably lost (F. Dinguemans per. com. ). According to Dettmer’s description it is
C. defonscolombei ,
because the lateral pronotum has transverse carinae, the dorsal part of the scutum is strongly transversally carinate and the forewings are infuscate. For these reasons we consider
Callaspidia rubricrus Dettmer, 1924
as a new synonymy of
C. defonscolombei Dahlbom, 1842
.

The original description of
Callaspidia areolata (Kieffer)
is much shorter, but Kieffer (1901a) mentions that this species is differentiated from the rest by the areolet, which is very clearly formed, a character that is refuted by Kieffer (1902) when he states that the basal vein of the areolet is not very noticeable; with respect to the rest of the features mentioned in both studies, we consider
Callaspidia areolata (Kieffer)
to be a new synonymy of
C. defonscolombei Dalhbom.

In the material deposited in CNCI we have found several specimens “in litera” determined by Provancher as
Callaspidia canadiensis
that have never been published and belong to
C. defonscolombei Dalhbom.
